questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with fatigue and a persistent pallor despite adequate nutrition. The parents report a family history of anemia. A skull X-ray is performed as part of the evaluation. Based on the skull X-ray appearance shown in the image, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Thalassemia

 

Option D:

 

Hair on end appearance is characteristically seen in Hemolytic anemias such as Thalassemia.

 

Thalassemia: Thalassemia, especially the severe forms like β-thalassemia major, leads to expansion of the bone marrow spaces in the skull due to ineffective erythropoiesis, which creates the "hair on end" appearance on X-rays, characterized by thickening of trabeculae and long vertical striations within the diploic space.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Raised ICP: Increased intracranial pressure can lead to several changes in the skull X-ray, such as a separation of sutures in children, erosion of the sella turcica, and sometimes, demineralization of the skull. However, it does not cause the "hair on end" appearance shown in the image.

 

Option B. Multiple Myeloma: Multiple myeloma is characterized by lytic lesions often referred to as "punched-out" lesions on X-ray. The classic "raindrop" skull appearance can be seen, but it does not present with the vertical striations characteristic of the "hair on end" appearance.

 

Option C. Megaloblastic Anemia: Megaloblastic anemia, caused by a deficiency of vitamin B12 or folic acid, can also lead to changes in the bone marrow and subsequent skull changes. However, the "hair on end" appearance is not typically seen with megaloblastic anemia.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The "hair on end" appearance on skull X-ray is characteristic of hemolytic anemias like thalassemia due to the expansion of diploic space and thickening of trabeculae, indicating the need for effective erythropoiesis.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 664

questions.text: A radiology resident is reviewing a thyroid ultrasound for evaluation of a nodule. Which of the following is NOT included in the American College of Radiology's Thyroid Imaging Reporting and Data System (ACR TI-RADS) criteria?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Vascularity

 

Option C:

 

Vascularity refers to the blood flow within a nodule as seen on Doppler ultrasound. While vascularity is assessed in thyroid nodules, it is not part of the ACR TI-RADS. TI-RADS is based on the nodule's composition, echogenicity, shape, margin, and echogenic foci, not vascularity.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Margin: Margins are evaluated in thyroid nodules to determine the risk of malignancy. TI-RADS includes margin assessment with descriptors like smooth, ill-defined, lobulated, or irregular to score the nodules.

 

Option B: Echogenicity: Echogenicity describes the brightness of a thyroid nodule compared to the surrounding thyroid tissue. TI-RADS uses echogenicity as a criterion, including anechoic, hyperechoic, isoechoic, and hypoechoic as descriptors.

 

Option D: Shape: The shape of a nodule, whether it is wider than tall or taller-than-wide, is a significant factor in TI-RADS. A taller-than-wide shape is more concerning for malignancy and is thus included in the TI-RADS scoring system.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Vascularity is not included in the ACR TI-RADS criteria for thyroid nodules. TI-RADS is utilized to stratify the risk of thyroid nodules based on their ultrasound characteristics, excluding vascularity, which aids medical students and residents in identifying nodules that may require further evaluation or intervention.

 

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 876

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents with a history of progressive vision loss in her right eye. An MRI of the orbit reveals a lesion with a characteristic appearance. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis based on the MRI findings?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Optic nerve sheath meningioma

 

Option A:

 

The given clinical scenario presenting with manifestations like gradual loss of visual acuity in the right eye and CT showing thickening of the optic nerve sheath complex with a tram track appearance point towards the diagnosis of optic nerve sheath meningioma.

 

Optic nerve sheath meningioma: Optic nerve sheath meningiomas are benign tumors that arise from the meningeal coverings of the optic nerve. They are typically slow-growing and can present with gradual loss of vision. MRI findings characteristic of optic nerve sheath meningioma include a thickened optic nerve with a "tram-track" appearance, where the optic nerve is seen separately from the sheath enhancement.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Optic nerve glioma: Optic nerve gliomas are typically seen in children and young adults and are often associated with neurofibromatosis type 1. MRI usually shows fusiform enlargement of the optic nerve with a kinking or tortuosity.

 

Option C. Retinoblastoma: Retinoblastoma is a malignant pediatric tumor of the retina that presents with leukocoria (white pupillary reflex) and vision loss. It is often identified by calcifications within the mass on CT rather than MRI.

 

Option D. Optic neuritis: Optic neuritis, commonly associated with multiple sclerosis, presents with acute vision loss and pain with eye movement. MRI might show an enhancing optic nerve, but typically without the thickening or the "tram-track" sign associated with meningioma.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The gradual loss of visual acuity in one eye, coupled with MRI evidence of optic nerve sheath complex thickening and a "tram-track" appearance, is indicative of an optic nerve sheath meningioma.

 

Tram-track appearance with ON seen separately: ON meningioma

 

 

Fusiform mass involving the optic nerve: ON Glioma

 

 

Retinoblastoma: A child with intra-ocular mass with calcification on CT

 

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 854

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the pediatric OPD by his parents with complaints of headache, vomiting, dizziness and unsteady gait for the past 2 months. What is the likely grade of the tumor on the basis of the image given below?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Grade 4

 

Option D:

 

The MRI images included in the question show an enhancing lesion in the 4th ventricle, and the correct answer indicated is Grade 4. The diagnosis is of medulloblastoma.

 

Medulloblastom:

  • Most common malignant brain tumor in children, predominantly found in the cerebellum.
  • Medulloblastomas are aggressive and classified as WHO grade IV tumors. This classification implies a high-grade tumor with a poor prognosis compared to lower-grade tumors.
  • Symptoms associated with medulloblastomas can include headache, vomiting (due to increased intracranial pressure), dizziness, and coordination issues, as seen in this case.

 

MRI Characteristics:

 

  • The key MRI feature mentioned is an enhancing lesion in the 4th ventricle, which is typical for medulloblastomas. These tumors often show contrast enhancement due to their high vascularity.
  • The location in the 4th ventricle is significant because it can affect the flow of cerebrospinal fluid, potentially leading to hydrocephalus, which could contribute to the symptoms of headache and vomiting.

 

Grade 4 Classification:

 

  • This grade indicates a highly malignant tumor with a propensity for rapid growth and worse clinical outcomes.
  • Treatment typically involves a combination of surgery, radiation, and chemotherapy, depending on the extent of the disease and the patient's condition

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tumor seen in the MRI above is classified as WHO grade 4 tumor.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 726

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient presented with a headache and altered sensorium. MRI was performed which revealed multiple rings enhancing lesions. MR spectroscopy showed a prominent lipid-lactate peak. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Tuberculoma

 

Option B:

 

Foci of infection which conglomerating ring enhancing lesions, common around brainstem.

 

Tuberculoma: Tuberculoma is central nervous system tuberculosis characterized by intracranial granulomas. On MRI, these can appear as ring-enhancing lesions, particularly around the brainstem. MR spectroscopy reveals a lipid-lactate peak due to necrosis within the lesion, which is a distinguishing feature in comparison to other infections.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Neurocysticercosis: Neurocysticercosis is a parasitic infection caused by the larval stage of Taenia solium, presenting with seizures, headaches, or other neurological symptoms. MRI findings often include cystic lesions with or without a scolex (the head of the larva), and ring-enhancing lesions when the cyst is dying. MR spectroscopy may show elevated choline and reduced N-acetyl aspartate (NAA), but a prominent lipid-lactate peak is not typical.

 

Option C. PML (Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy): PML is a demyelinating disease caused by the JC virus, most commonly in immunocompromised patients. MRI shows non-enhancing white matter lesions without mass effect, typically in the parieto-occipital regions. MR spectroscopy in PML typically shows a reduction in NAA, reflecting neuronal loss or damage, without a prominent lipid-lactate peak.

 

Option D. Cryptococcomas: Cryptococcomas are localized granulomatous lesions caused by Cryptococcus, seen in both immunocompetent and immunocompromised individuals. MRI may show multiple ring-enhancing lesions, similar to tuberculoma, but spectroscopy differs, usually without a significant lipid-lactate peak.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with headaches and altered sensorium, multiple ring-enhancing lesions on MRI, accompanied by a prominent lipid-lactate peak on MR spectroscopy, are indicative of tuberculoma, where the lipid-lactate peak suggests necrosis within the lesions.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 716

questions.text: A patient is found to have a cerebellopontine angle mass. The differential diagnosis can include all except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tuberculoma

 

Option C:

 

Tuberculoma does not cause cerebellopontine angle mass. They are ring-enhancing lesions within the brain parenchyma, most commonly around the brainstem.

 

Acoustic schwannoma is the most common cerebellopontine tumor (90%).

 

CP angle Tumors-Mnemonic: “SAME”:

 

• S: Schwannoma

 

 

• A: Arachnoid cyst

• M: Meningioma, Metastases

• E: Epidermoid cyst

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Meningioma: Meningiomas are tumors that originate from the meninges, the protective layers surrounding the brain and spinal cord. They are often benign and slow-growing. At the cerebellopontine angle (CPA), they may present as extra-axial masses that can compress adjacent structures, including cranial nerves. Imaging typically shows a well-defined lesion that is isointense or hypointense on T1-weighted images and enhances with contrast.

 

Option B. Acoustic Schwannoma (Vestibular Schwannoma): Acoustic schwannomas are benign tumors that arise from the Schwann cells of the vestibular nerve. They are the most common tumors of the CPA, accounting for the majority of lesions in this location. On MRI, they typically appear as well-circumscribed, iso- or hypointense on T1, hyperintense on T2, and enhance with contrast.

 

Option D. Epidermoid Cyst: Epidermoid cysts are benign, congenital lesions arising from ectodermal cells. In the CPA, they can mimic the appearance of acoustic schwannomas but typically have a "pearly" appearance on MRI, being hypointense on T1 and hyperintense on T2 with no enhancement post-contrast, due to their cholesterol content and desquamated cell layers.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tuberculoma typically presents as a ring-enhancing lesion within the brain parenchyma and is an unlikely cause of a cerebellopontine angle mass, in contrast to acoustic schwannoma, which is the most common CPA tumor and typically demonstrates enhancement on imaging.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 764

questions.text: Physiological calcification is seen in all of the structures except:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Red Nucleus

 

Option D:

 

The red nucleus, located in the midbrain, is involved in motor coordination.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Pineal gland: Physiological calcification of the pineal gland is commonly seen on imaging and is typically considered a normal finding, particularly in adults.

 

Option B. Habenular commissure: The habenular commissure, which connects the left and right habenula, can also exhibit physiological calcification and is often visible on radiographic imaging, including CT scans of the brain.

 

Option C. Dura: Calcification of the dura, including the falx cerebri and tentorium cerebelli, is another example of a normal variant. These calcifications are generally benign and detected incidentally during imaging for other reasons.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Physiological calcifications in the pineal gland, habenular commissure, and dura are common and typically benign findings on imaging. The red nucleus, however, does not typically exhibit physiological calcification, and its presence may indicate an underlying pathological process.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with a history of multiple endocrine disorders presents with movement abnormalities. A head CT scan reveals basal ganglia calcification. Which of the following conditions is least likely associated with this radiographic finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hemochromatosis

 

Option C:

 

Hemochromatosis is characterized by excessive iron deposition in various organs, including the liver and heart, but typically does not cause basal ganglia calcification. This condition is often related to mutations in the HFE gene and can lead to organ dysfunction due to iron overload.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Hypoparathyroidism: Calcifications in the basal ganglia are a well-documented phenomenon in patients with hypoparathyroidism. The reduction in parathyroid hormone can lead to a disruption in calcium and phosphate homeostasis, resulting in intracranial calcifications.

 

Option B. Physiological aging: In some patients, particularly the elderly, basal ganglia calcification may be a physiological process associated with aging. These calcifications are typically asymptomatic and are often incidental findings.

 

Option D. Fahr syndrome: Fahr syndrome is a rare, genetic, neurodegenerative disorder that specifically involves calcifications in the basal ganglia and other brain regions, often leading to neurological symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Basal ganglia calcifications can be associated with several conditions, including hypoparathyroidism, physiological aging, and Fahr syndrome, but are not typically a feature of hemochromatosis.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 628

questions.text:
A 60-year-old patient presents with headaches and a recent seizure. CT and MRI of the head reveal an intracranial lesion with evidence of calcification. Which group of conditions would most commonly include calcified brain tumors?

 

  1. Glioblastoma multiforme
  2. Craniopharyngioma
  3. Oligodendroglioma
  4. Ependymoma
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2, 3, 4

 

Explanation:

 

Commonly calcified lesions are:

 

• Oligodendrogliomas

• Choroid plexus tumors

• Ependymoma

• Craniopharyngioma

• Teratoma

• Chordoma

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 716

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of back pain and radicular symptoms underwent myelography for further evaluation. The myelogram showed expansion of the contrast-filled space around the spinal cord. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for this imaging finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Intradural extramedullary tumor

 

Option B:

 

These tumors are located within the dural sheath but outside the spinal cord. Myelography would reveal an expansion of the contrast-filled space because the tumor displaces the cord and spreads the contrast around it. Neurofibroma and meningioma are common types of intradural extramedullary tumors.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Intramedullary Tumor: An intramedullary tumor is located within the spinal cord parenchyma. On myelography, it may show an irregularity of the contrast column but will not typically cause an expansion of the contrast-filled space. Instead, it might cause a blockage or displacement of the contrast.

 

Option C. Spinal Dysraphism: Spinal dysraphism refers to a group of neural tube defects that result in an incomplete fusion of the spine. In myelography, findings vary depending on the type of dysraphism but may include defects in the contrast column indicative of the spinal canal's congenital abnormalities, not necessarily expansion of the space.

 

Option D. Extradural Tumor: Extradural tumors are located outside the dural sheath. On myelography, these may compress the dura and potentially narrow the contrast-filled space, contrasting with the widening caused by intradural extramedullary tumors.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In myelography, an expansion of the contrast-filled space is indicative of an intradural extramedullary tumor, which displaces the spinal cord and dura, allowing more room for contrast material in the subarachnoid space.

 

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 822

questions.text: All of the following can present as a ring-enhancing lesion on imaging except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. PML

 

Option D:

 

PML-progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy presents as asymmetrical white matter hyperintensities.

 

PML is a demyelinating disease caused by reactivation of the JC virus, primarily affecting the white matter. It does not typically present as ring-enhancing lesions; instead, it shows asymmetrical white matter hyperintensities on T2-weighted MRI.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tuberculoma: Tuberculomas are intracranial lesions caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and often present as ring-enhancing lesions due to their granulomatous nature on imaging modalities like CT or MRI.

 

Option B. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis, especially in immunocompromised patients, can lead to the formation of ring-enhancing brain lesions, representing the body's inflammatory response to the cysts formed by the parasite Toxoplasma gondii.

 

Option C. Brain Abscess: A brain abscess is a collection of pus within the brain parenchyma, surrounded by a capsule. On imaging, it typically shows a ring-enhancing lesion due to the encapsulated inflammatory process.

 

Educational Objective:


Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) typically presents with asymmetrical white matter hyperintensities rather than ring-enhancing lesions. Ring-enhancing lesions on neuroimaging are more characteristic of conditions like tuberculoma, toxoplasmosis, and brain abscesses.

 

Ring-enhancing brain lesions can be remembered as MAGIC DR:

 

M: metastasis

A: abscess

G: glioblastoma

I: infarct (subacute phase) or inflammatory (neurocysticercosis, tuberculoma)

C: contusion

D: demyelinating disease (classically incomplete rim of enhancement)

R: radiation necrosis or resolving hematoma

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 900

questions.text: A T2 weighted MRI was done for a child who presented with delayed milestones. It showed hyperintensity in frontal white matter with bilateral and symmetrical involvement. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alexander’s disease

 

Option B:

 

Alexander's disease is characterized by early involvement of subcortical white matter with a preference for the frontal lobe.

Dysmyelinating diseases, also known as, leukodystrophies are inherited neurodegenerative disorders that impair myelin integrity in the brain and peripheral nerves.

 

Alexander's Disease: Alexander's Disease is characterized by the early involvement of subcortical white matter with a preference for the frontal lobe. It is a dysmyelinating disease that impairs myelin integrity, often leading to megalencephaly and seizures.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Canavan Disease: Canavan Disease is a leukodystrophy that presents with spongy degeneration of the white matter in the brain. MRI typically shows diffuse white matter hyperintensity in both hemispheres, which may involve subcortical U-fibers.

 

Option C. X-linked Adrenoleukodystrophy: This genetic disorder affects the nervous system and adrenal glands, leading to progressive brain damage. On MRI, there is typically involvement of the white matter with a posterior-to-anterior pattern, which can be asymmetrical and enhances with contrast.

 

Option D. Metachromatic Leukodystrophy: This inherited metabolic disorder affects the formation and maintenance of myelin. MRI findings include white matter changes that are progressive and symmetrical but are not typically frontally predominant.

 

Educational Objective:


Alexander's Disease is most likely to present with early bilateral and symmetrical frontal white matter involvement on T2 weighted MRI in a child with delayed milestones. It is a leukodystrophy characterized by dysmyelination and often presents with megalencephaly and seizures.

 

Other examples of leukodystrophies and their clues include:

 

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 798

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents with a sudden onset of pulsatile proptosis and a red, painful eye. On physical examination, you notice dilated scleral vessels and her eye is protruding in a pulsatile fashion. A bruit is audible over the right temple. To confirm the suspected diagnosis, you order a CT scan which reveals a specific finding. CT scan finding in carotid cavernous sinus fistula is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Enlarged superior ophthalmic vein

 

Option A:

 

Caroticocavernous fistulas represent abnormal communication between the carotid circulation and the cavernous sinus.

A carotid cavernous fistula (CCF) shows a typical pulsatile proptosis, enlarged sclera vessels, a prominent cavernous sinus & superior ophthalmic vein, enlarged extraocular muscles, and dirty orbital fat (due to edema & venous engorgement).

 

An enlarged superior ophthalmic vein is typically seen in a carotid-cavernous fistula, representing an abnormal communication between the carotid arterial system and the cavernous sinus. This can lead to venous congestion, edema, and the clinical signs noted in the patient.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. An enlarged inferior ophthalmic vein is not typically seen in a carotid-cavernous fistula and is not associated with the classic symptoms of pulsatile proptosis.

 

Option C. Enlargement of the superior ophthalmic artery is not characteristic of a carotid-cavernous fistula and does not produce the symptoms described.

 

Option D. Similar to option C, an enlarged inferior ophthalmic artery is not a finding in carotid-cavernous fistula and would not account for the clinical presentation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The characteristic CT scan finding in a carotid-cavernous fistula is an enlarged superior ophthalmic vein, reflects the venous congestion caused by the abnormal arteriovenous communication within the cavernous sinus. This finding, in conjunction with the clinical symptoms of pulsatile proptosis, painful red eye, and audible bruit, is diagnostic of a carotid-cavernous fistula.

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 850

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents with bitemporal hemianopia. CT is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Craniopharyngioma

 

Option C:

 

A calcified lesion in the suprasellar region suggests craniopharyngioma. It is derived from Rathke's pouch.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Pituitary adenomas are seen in the sellar region in adults. Macroadenomas are seen as snowman or figure of eight appearances.

 

Option B: Meningioma is a supratentorial tumor, mainly in the parasagittal region. A classical Dural tail is seen.

 

Option D: Oligodendroglioma is exclusively found in the cerebral hemispheres, most commonly in the frontal lobes. Up to 90% of oligodendrogliomas contain visible calcification on CT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The CT image showing a calcified lesion in the suprasellar region, with the clinical presentation of bitemporal hemianopia in a child, is suggestive of craniopharyngioma. Craniopharyngiomas are typically derived from Rathke's pouch, are common in the pediatric population, and often present with a combination of cystic and solid components, with calcifications noted on imaging.

 

Reference – Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 742

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with a history of recurrent headaches. An MRI is performed, revealing a homogeneously enhancing mass. Based on the imaging findings provided, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Meningioma

 

Option B:

 

The given T1 post-contrast MRI is suggestive of meningioma. It is seen as homogeneously enhanced mass in the midline, arising from falx showing the DURAL TAIL sign.

 

Origin: arachnoid cap cells of the meninges: Female predominance, which may be related to the presence of progesterone receptors

 

Association: NF-2

 

On T1 and T2 weighted imaging, typical meningiomas appear as Dural-based masses that are isointense to grey matter and show vivid contrast enhancement on MRI and CT.

 

Meningioma Meningiomas arise from the meninges and are more common in females. These are often dural-based, extra-axial tumors that may exhibit the 'dural tail sign' on T1 post-contrast MRI, showing homogeneous enhancement. They are typically isointense or slightly hyperintense to gray matter on T1-weighted images and enhance vividly with contrast. They can be associated with neurofibromatosis type 2.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Oligodendroglioma: Oligodendrogliomas are typically found within the cerebral hemispheres and often involve the frontal lobes. On MRI, they can appear as heterogeneous masses due to the presence of calcifications, hemorrhage, or cystic changes. They are characterized by a "fried egg" appearance histologically.

 

Option C. Pituitary Adenoma: Pituitary adenomas can cause headaches and visual disturbances due to compression of the optic chiasm. On imaging, they typically appear as well-circumscribed lesions within the sellar region. Large adenomas, known as macroadenomas, can cause an expanded sella turcica on MRI.

 

Option D. Acoustic Schwannoma:  Acoustic schwannomas, also known as vestibular schwannomas, are benign tumors that arise from Schwann cells of the vestibulocochlear nerve. They are located in the cerebellopontine angle and can cause hearing loss, tinnitus, and balance difficulties. On MRI, they typically show as well-circumscribed, enhancing masses near the internal acoustic meatus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The T1 post-contrast MRI showing a homogeneously enhanced mass in the midline with the dural tail sign is suggestive of meningioma, a tumor arising from the arachnoid cap cells of the meninges, showing female predominance and possible association with neurofibromatosis type 2. Meningiomas are typically dural-based and show vivid contrast enhancement on MRI and CT.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 734

questions.text: A 6-year-old child with a history of transient ischemic attacks and several episodes of weakness is referred for diagnostic evaluation. On physical examination, there is a noticeable murmur around the child's temple. Digital Subtraction Angiography (DSA) is performed, revealing the characteristic imaging shown.The following appearance of DSA is seen in:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Moya-Moya disease

 

Option B:

 

Moya-Moya disease is Japanese for ‘puff of smoke’, the DSA appearance of collateral vessels on cerebral angiography.

 

Moya-Moya disease is characterized by a 'puff of smoke' appearance due to the proliferation of collateral networks as a compensatory mechanism for the stenosis of the intracranial arteries.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Cavernous infarction typically does not show the 'puff of smoke' appearance on DSA, which is specific to collateral vessel formation.

 

Option C. Cerebral infarction generally shows areas of restricted blood flow on imaging, not the network of collateral vessels seen in Moya-Moya disease.

 

Option D. Carotid artery thrombosis typically presents with an abrupt cutoff in the artery on DSA, not the formation of collateral circulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Moya-Moya disease, is characterized by progressive stenosis of the internal carotid arteries with subsequent development of a characteristic "puff of smoke" appearance due to the formation of collateral vessels. This angiographic finding is a hallmark of the disease and is often associated with clinical presentations of transient ischemic attacks and ischemic symptoms in young children.

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 750

questions.text: A patient presents with symptoms suggestive of a central nervous system infection. MRI brain imaging is performed, revealing characteristic findings that help narrow down the differential diagnosis. What condition is associated with a "soap bubble" appearance on MRI brain imaging?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cryptococcal cysts

 

Option B:

 

  • Gelatinous pseudocysts caused by Cryptococcus tend to give a “soap bubble” appearance on MRI.
  • Dilated perivascular spaces and basal ganglia pseudocysts are two of the most commonly described MRI features.

 

Cryptococcal cysts may present with a "soap bubble" appearance due to gelatinous pseudocysts formed by Cryptococcus, typically seen in the basal ganglia region.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Tubercular meningitis on MRI is characterized by basal meningeal enhancement, hydrocephalus, and infarctions, without the "soap bubble" appearance.

 

Option C. Neurocysticercosis on MRI shows a "starry sky" pattern with vesicular cysts and a characteristic dot sign representing the scolex within the cyst.

 

Option D. Ependymoma is a neoplastic condition that does not typically present with a "soap bubble" appearance on MRI.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cryptococcal cysts on MRI are associated with a "soap bubble" appearance due to the presence of gelatinous pseudocysts caused by Cryptococcus, most notably affecting the basal ganglia and perivascular spaces.

 

 

Soap bubble appearance-Cryptococcomas

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 770

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman was hospitalized at week 10 of gestation because of severe hyperemesis. At admission the patient appeared restless and confused and severe hyponatremia (serum sodium 107 mmol/L) and hypokalemia (serum potassium 1.1 mmol/L) were detected. Active and simultaneous correction of these imbalances were performed, but the patient deteriorated further. MRI was done and shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Osmotic demyelination syndrome

 

Option D:

 

Piglet snout or the trident sign is one of the characteristic findings on MRI T2 in central pontine myelinolysis (osmotic demyelination syndrome), which is a noninflammatory demyelinating disease of the white matter tracts traversing the pons.

 

Osmotic demyelination syndrome: A condition that can occur with rapid correction of hyponatremia, leading to demyelination of neurons, particularly in the pons. MRI findings typically show areas of T2 hyperintensity in the pons, often with characteristic configurations like the "trident sign," consistent with the provided image and clinical scenario.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Wilson disease: Wilson disease is an inherited disorder causing copper accumulation in the liver, brain, and other vital organs. MRI may show high signal intensity in the basal ganglia on T2-weighted images, but the rapid onset of neurological symptoms post-electrolyte correction is not characteristic.

 

Option B. Multiple system atrophy type C: This is a sporadic, progressive neurodegenerative disorder affecting the cerebellum, causing ataxia and cerebellar signs. MRI findings include atrophy of the cerebellum and brainstem, not consistent with the acute presentation and characteristic MRI findings described here.

 

Option C. Progressive supranuclear palsy: A neurological disorder that causes problems with balance, movement, vision, and thinking. MRI may show atrophy in the midbrain but does not present with acute demyelination or electrolyte imbalance-related symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Osmotic demyelination syndrome, also known as central pontine myelinolysis, should be suspected in patients with rapid correction of hyponatremia who subsequently develop neurological symptoms. The MRI findings of a "trident sign" are indicative of this condition, characterized by demyelination in the pons.

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 774

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis according to the given image?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pseudoaneurysm of internal carotid artery

 

Option B:

 

The given image shows a digital subtraction angiography of ICA and it shows an outpouching of the contrast suggestive of a pseudoaneurysm of the internal carotid artery as marked by the arrow.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. A carotid-cavernous fistula (CCF) is the result of an abnormal vascular connection between the internal carotid artery (ICA) and the cavernous sinus. Pulsatile proptosis of eye would be the pathognomic clinical finding. DSA would reveal enlarged draining superior ophthalmic vein.

 

 

Option C. Tumor blush of angiofibroma would show feeder vessels from internal maxillary artery of ECA.

 

Option D. Extensive head and neck hemangioma would show multiple tortuous vessels supplying a mass which is not seen here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A pseudoaneurysm of the internal carotid artery on digital subtraction angiography is identified as an outpouching of contrast from the internal carotid artery, consistent with a pseudoaneurysm.

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 754

questions.text: A A 35-year-old woman presents with a 3-month history of neck swelling. Contrast-enhanced computed tomography (CECT) of the neck reveals a lesion located in the carotid space with specific imaging features. Based on the imaging characteristics presented, what is the most likely diagnosis for the neck swelling observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paraganglioma

 

Option A:

 

A large enhancing soft tissue mass in the anterior triangle of the right neck at the carotid bifurcation with characteristic splaying of the internal carotid artery and external carotid artery is noted. This is known as the Lyre sign

 

This is typical of Carotid body tumor or Paraganglioma.

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Meningioma typically presents as an intracranial tumor rather than a neck mass, and would not display the vascular splaying characteristic of the Lyre sign.

 

Option C. Schwannoma, while it may occur in the neck, is usually associated with the peripheral nerves and does not typically splay the carotid arteries.

 

Option D. Ependymoma is a central nervous system tumor arising from ependymal cells lining the ventricular system and is not consistent with the imaging or location described in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct diagnosis for a lesion that causes splaying of the internal and external carotid arteries at the carotid bifurcation, as seen on CECT, is a paraganglioma, which is also known as a carotid body tumor.

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 860

questions.text: A 32-year-old female presents to her primary care physician with complaints of numbness and tingling in her right leg. She also reports that her vision in her left eye has been blurry for the past few weeks. The symptoms have been gradually getting worse over the past month. On further evaluation, the patient has difficulty with balance and coordination, and her reflexes are brisk. An MRI of the brain and spinal cord is ordered, which is shown in the image. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Multiple sclerosis

 

Option D:

 

The image shows hyperintense lesions arranged perpendicular to the lateral ventricles in a triangular configuration (Dawson's fingers), which are common in multiple sclerosis.

IOC for multiple sclerosis: CE-MRI

 

Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disease of the CNS, and the MRI often shows Dawson's fingers, which are periventricular lesions oriented perpendicular to the lateral ventricles.

 

Explanation -

 

Option A. Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder causing copper accumulation in tissues, usually presenting with hepatic and psychiatric symptoms, and the MRI may show basal ganglia changes, not the pattern seen in the provided image.

 

Option B. Multiple system atrophy is characterized by autonomic dysfunction, parkinsonism, and cerebellar signs, with MRI typically showing abnormalities in the cerebellum, pons, and basal ganglia.

 

Option C. Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy is a rare, often fatal demyelinating disease caused by the JC virus, typically seen in immunocompromised patients, and the MRI would show non-enhancing white matter lesions without mass effect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The provided MRI shows hyperintense lesions characteristic of multiple sclerosis, arranged perpendicular to the lateral ventricles, known as Dawson's fingers, consistent with the patient's clinical symptoms of sensory disturbances and blurred vision.

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 772

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with complaints of chronic sinusitis. Despite appropriate medical therapy, her symptoms persist. A computed tomography (CT) scan of the paranasal sinuses is performed, and an abnormal finding is noted in the sinonasal anatomy. Identify the following structure marked with white arrow:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Concha bullosa

 

Option A:

 

Concha Bullosa: This refers to the pneumatization (air-filled cavity within a bone) of the middle turbinate. This is a common anatomical variation and can be asymptomatic but may contribute to sinusitis if it obstructs sinus drainage pathways.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Haller Cell: These are ethmoidal air cells that are located along the inferomedial orbital floor, also known as infraorbital ethmoidal air cells. When enlarged, Haller cells can impinge on the maxillary sinus ostium and contribute to recurrent sinus infections.

 

Option C. Bulla Ethmoidalis: This is the largest and most constant of the anterior ethmoid air cells. It forms part of the lateral nasal wall and its enlargement can narrow the ethmoidal infundibulum, potentially causing obstruction of the osteomeatal complex, leading to sinusitis.

 

Option D. Pneumatized Superior Turbinate: Rarely, the superior turbinate can become pneumatized. This condition is less commonly associated with sinusitis compared to the other anatomical variations.

 

Educational Objective:
 

Concha bullosa refers to the pneumatization of the middle turbinate and is a common variation that can sometimes obstruct sinus drainage, thereby contributing to chronic sinusitis.

 

Haller cells

 

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 858

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presents with new-onset seizures and progressively worsening headaches. An MRI with contrast reveals the image as shown below. Based on the image and clinical presentation, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Glioblastoma

 

Option A:

 

The given MRI finding is showing heterogeneously enhancing necrotic butterfly glioma involving contralateral hemisphere suggestive of Glioblastoma multiforme (GBM), the most aggressive and malignant primary brain tumor in adults.

 

Glioblastoma: Glioblastoma Multiforme (GBM) is the most common and aggressive primary malignant brain tumor in adults, often presenting with rapid onset of symptoms including headaches and seizures. On imaging, it typically appears as a heterogeneously enhancing lesion with areas of necrosis and a characteristic "butterfly" pattern as it crosses the midline via the corpus callosum.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ependymoma: Ependymomas are glial tumors derived from the ependymal lining of the ventricular system. In adults, they often occur in the spinal cord. Intracranially, they are usually found in the fourth ventricle. Imaging typically shows a well-circumscribed lesion that can enhance uniformly.

 

Option C. Meningioma: Meningiomas are benign tumors arising from the meninges. They usually attach to the dura and compress the brain without invading it, often showing as extra-axial lesions with a dural tail sign on imaging.

 

Option D. Acoustic schwannoma: Also known as vestibular schwannomas, these benign tumors arise from the Schwann cells of the vestibulocochlear nerve and are usually located at the cerebellopontine angle, not within the cerebral hemispheres. Imaging would not typically show a lesion like the one in the provided MRI.

 

Educational Objective:
 

A contrast-enhanced MRI revealing a heterogeneously enhancing lesion with central necrosis and midline crossing is suggestive of Glioblastoma multiforme, the most aggressive primary brain tumor, which is classified as a WHO grade IV astrocytoma.Top of Form

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 720

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents with headaches and new-onset seizures following the consumption of pork. An MRI of the brain, as displayed, reveals characteristic findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Neurocysticercosis

 

Option A:

 

The MRI brain shows multiple cysticerci cyst with a dot sign within the brain known as starry sky appearance seen in neurocysticercosis.

 

Neurocysticercosis: Neurocysticercosis is an infection of the nervous system caused by the larval stage of the pork tapeworm, Taenia solium. It results from the accidental ingestion of eggs found in contaminated food. The MRI shows cysts with a central scolex ("dot sign"), referred to as a "starry sky appearance," which is highly suggestive of neurocysticercosis.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Tuberculoma: A tuberculoma is a localized tuberculous infection in the brain that may appear as ring-enhancing lesions on MRI. The history of pork consumption and the specific MRI appearance are less typical for tuberculoma.

 

Option C. Toxoplasmosis: Toxoplasmosis in the brain can present with ring-enhancing lesions, especially in immunocompromised patients, but the imaging and history provided do not strongly suggest this diagnosis.

 

Option D. Cryptococcomas: Cryptococcomas are masses caused by the fungal infection Cryptococcus, typically occurring in immunocompromised individuals. MRI findings and clinical history do not align with cryptococcosis.

 

Educational Objective:
 

The most likely diagnosis in a patient presenting with seizures and characteristic MRI findings following the consumption of pork is neurocysticercosis. The MRI findings include multiple cystic lesions with a central scolex, indicative of the parasitic infection.

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 766

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a palpable, pulsatile neck mass at the level of the carotid bifurcation. The mass is mobile at right angles to the vessels but fixed in the direction of the vessels. The following appearance known as Lyre sign is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Carotid body tumor

 

Explanation:

 

  • The above angiographic image represents Lyre sign which refers to splaying of the internal and external carotid artery at the bifurcation of the common carotid artery caused by carotid body tumor. Classically described on angiography, it is also visible on CT angiography.

 

Note – Shamblin classification is done for Carotid Body Tumor in relation to the carotid vessels

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 218

questions.text: A 2-year-old child with delayed developmental milestones presents to the OPD. T2 weighted MRI is performed, and the imaging result is shown. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Metachromatic leukodystrophy

 

Option D:

 

  • Tigroid appearance is seen in metachromatic leukodystrophy.
  • Dysmyelinating diseases, also known as, leukodystrophies are inherited neurodegenerative disorders that impair myelin integrity in the brain and peripheral nerves.

 

Option D:

 

Metachromatic leukodystrophy, a disorder affecting myelin metabolism, characteristically shows a tigroid pattern on MRI due to demyelination with preservation of perivascular myelin, which is consistent with the MRI image provided.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Canavan disease is a leukodystrophy that typically presents with macrocephaly, developmental delay, and a characteristic spongy degeneration of the brain on MRI but does not show the pattern seen here.

 

Option B. Alexander's disease is another form of leukodystrophy that often presents early in life with seizures, megalencephaly, and developmental delay. MRI typically shows frontal predominance, not the pattern demonstrated.

 

Option C. X-linked adrenoleukodystrophy usually presents in boys with progressive neurological decline and adrenal insufficiency. MRI would typically show white matter abnormalities in the parieto-occipital region.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The tigroid pattern on T2 weighted MRI is characteristic of metachromatic leukodystrophy, an inherited leukodystrophy marked by impaired myelin metabolism and progressive demyelination in the central nervous system.

 

Other examples of leukodystrophies and their clues include:

 

 

Reference - Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition, Page No 798

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presented with dementia, involuntary hand and finger movement. The MRI image is given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Huntington's disease

 

Option C:

 

  • Coronal T1 weighted image of Huntington’s disease shows bilateral atrophy of caudate nuclei and compensatory dilatation of lateral ventricle, a finding known as box car ventricles.
  • Huntington's disease is an autosomal dominant neurodegenerative disease that primarily affects young adults.
  • A cytosine-adenine-guanine (CAG) trinucleotide repeat expansion in the huntingtin (HTT) gene on chromosome 4p causes it.
  • It is characterized by choreiform movements, psychiatric problems, and dementia.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Wilson’s disease on an MRI shows abnormal T2 hyperintensity in the putamina is the most common abnormality.

 

Option B. Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease shows cortical ribboning and pulvinar hyperintensity.

 

Option D. Parkinson’s Disease on an MRI shows loss of normal swallow tail appearance of susceptibility signal pattern in the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct diagnosis when MRI shows bilateral atrophy of the caudate nuclei with subsequent dilatation of the lateral ventricles, along with clinical presentation of choreiform movements and cognitive impairment, is Huntington's disease.

 

Reference– Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology Essentials, Second Edition
